But that reasoning can not be applied to this great charter. If all men are created equal, that is final. If they are endowed with inalienable rights, that is final. If governments derive their just powers from the consent of the governed, that is final. No advance, no progress can be made beyond these propositions. If anyone wishes to deny their truth or their soundness, the only direction in which he can proceed historically is not forward, but backward toward the time when there was no equality, no rights of the individual, no rule of the people. Those who wish to proceed in that direction can not lay claim to progress. They are reactionary. Originalism is nonsense on stilts for dozens of different reasons. Just one of them: the founders did not believe that their intentions mattered in interpreting the constitution. We know this because they were educated in common law, and at common-law the intentions of a document writer do not count in interpreting the document. But your question should not be limited to this constitutional topic. Rather you ask how reasonably intelligent and serious people can believe anything that is clearly false. Creationism comes to mind. The answer is that for most people, beliefs are a way of showing loyalty to their tribe. This is what keeps most religions going. To say you believe something doesn’t mean you believe it’s really true, it means you want to belong to a tribe of people who will protect you, so you mouth the same mottos and slogans that other members of your tribe utter. For most people, their belief statements are really like cheers for a team at a football game. Supporters of Donald Trump today do this all the time. “Lock her up. Send them back.“ Humans are tribal because the tribe is what keeps us feeling safe from all sorts of dangers. People take their tribal slogans very seriously. The best example now in the constitution is those who claim the second amendment provides a personal right to pack heat in violation of state law. This is absolutely not what the second amendment says. In fact it says almost opposite, since it protects the power of states to choose how they organize their state militias. But for fearful people, feeling that they belong to a tribe that loves guns will make them feel safe, so it’s really easy to understand how serious people believe in this nonsense.

That is a good question, and yet there are many who do. I am reading Neil Gorsuch’s new book, “A Republic, if you can keep it,” and it extolls the virtues of originalism as the only interpretive method to interpret the Constitution. What he does not discuss at all in the book is the Heller decision and how wording that had a meaning in 1787 in the 2nd Amendment, which Scalia (who he loved) called prefatory language. 4,500 words including 39 signatories, and the convention delegates added a few words with no binding impact. He also does not explain how first amendment jurisprudence works, with the admonition being Congress shall make no law…. Finally, he refers to Dred Scott as a matter of a living constitution.

Because we have an understanding that words mean specific things according to the context in which they are used. And the meaning of legal words, specifically, should be immutable in accordance with their context. Laws are crafted to address specific issues and the wording of those laws is chosen for use within that context, giving them a certain meaning and definition. To change the meaning of the words is to change the meaning and application of the law without going through the proper processes. Language changes over time, as does the common definitions of many words, but the law should never be so casually altered. For the objective rule of law to be effective, the meaning and intent of the law when debated and passed must be the meaning and intent that is applied, today and tomorrow. If laws need to be updated, altered or amended, there is a process for doing so. That process has nothing to do with arbitrary or activist redefinition of terms. Judges are tasked with the proper application of law in deciding cases. They are constrained by their oaths to follow the law as written. As the Constitution is the foundation for all legal authority in the country, the laws set down within and in accordance with that document must be applied as the words written were understood in the context of when they were written and approved. Otherwise, the “rule of law” (as well as the guarantee of equality before the law for all citizens) becomes suspect. The Constitution is the basis for the Rule of Law in this country and is, literally, the Law of the Land. Thus, common sense and justice mandate that judges utilize an Originalist understanding of the Constitution.
